channel.title: Hello
channel.description: Hi my name is "Dunder Mifflin" and I am not new to this forum. I was simply tired of my main account name and I basically got rep for bullshit reasons. So I want to start a new clean slate, and prove myself to the community. I code java and do GFX, and if anyone has any questions or needs help im here, give me a PM :). Alright guys, ill see you later :D

Everyone has their preference but all I’m saying is that English teachers and professors generally mark down (because it sounds weird in their head) for using contractions.

You were home schooled, honestly, I think it would be different.[/quote]
I thought he took online classes?

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

What do you think you are doing!

What do you think (your) doing! sounds better

Read full topic

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

You’re (sounds like your) and You are. If I said it out loud, I felt that You are would sound better in my sentence. It wouldn’t be circumstantial to me.

You are really going to do this?
You’re (your) really going to do this?

Read full topic

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Say that out loud though. ‘You are’ doesn’t flow well, which is one of the reasons they have that contraction anyway!

Examples where ‘You are’ is probably better:

You are [adjective]
You are such a [noun]
You are a(n) [adjective]

Read full topic

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

Davidi2:

Nah, you’re and you are are both fine. It depends on the flow of the sentence as to which you should use.

Actually, contractions are shunned by most English teachers. You are and you’re: “Do you honestly think you are writing less?” You (3) are (3) = 6 - You’re (6) not counting the space in between.

Read full topic

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Nah, you’re and you are are both fine. It depends on the flow of the sentence as to which you should use.

Read full topic

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:23, topic:408769”][quote author=LilXCj link=topic=510048.msg3707257#msg3707257 date=1313111977]

Nice job David, you muted a kid for following the rules how they are stated. I use to think you were a great person for the job but now I question your maturity and ability to handle it.

You dont know anything that happened before he posted, he deleted a whole argument of evidence that you didnt even see. You are basing your evidence on how you thought he handled things. But your wrong, as usual. So just stop, the argument is over. Leave it alone.

you’re*

trolololololo

Actually, using contractions will lower your essay score with any English teacher.
[/quote]

He was correcting the ‘your’.[/quote]

I still stand by the fact that contractions lower your essays impact overall.

Read full topic

item.title: Hello
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Andrew Ferguson, post:6, topic:408769”]Nice job David, you muted a kid for following the rules how they are stated. I use to think you were a great person for the job but now I question your maturity and ability to handle it.[/quote]I suggest you look at his previous posts as well before making accusations.

More than ~90% of them are flame or spam. It wasn’t just for this thread. Though yes this thread contributed to it, he broke the rules himself trying to get this thread locked by flaming everyone and questioning a moderators actions in public rather than PM (read the rules if you don’t understand what I mean there)

Also look, it says moderated, not muted (I also gave him the lowest level moderation possible, one day. I was actually told off by a different mod for making it so low :P)

I’ve said it before, I’m willing to explain any decision I make if people want to question it.

Read full topic
